title: The Boeing 737 MAX Question Is About Price, Not Sales
sub_head: Ryanair’s decision to buy another 75 units of the plane is good for Boeing, but the deal probably comes at a discount
body:
Everything has its price. Boeing ’s chief concern is just how low it needs to be.
Two weeks after the Federal Aviation Administration approved the Boeing 737 MAX for passenger flights, the jet already has a big firm order on the table. On Thursday, European low-cost leader Ryanair confirmed that it would exercise the option to buy a further 75 units, on top of 135 previously ordered.
Shares in the Chicago-based plane maker, which has estimated the cost of the MAX debacle at around $20 billion, rose almost 8%. To meet scheduled production rates, the company needs to ship out the 450 MAX planes it has in storage, about 100 of which no longer have a prospective buyer and need to be remarketed.
Yet it shouldn’t be a surprise that the plane is selling again.
Because aircraft aren’t consumer products, even the biggest scandals are unlikely to push a model out of the market. The infamous McDonnell Douglas DC-10 carried passengers for decades after being grounded. Airlines facing any customer backlash could probably get away with subtle rebranding in fuselages and onboard safety cards. Ryanair labels its custom high-capacity MAX the “737-8200.”
